prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 99.7 and Dec = -29.44 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 99.7  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -29.44  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 25.48, Dec = -17.9) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 25.48  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -17.9  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08783511661023706. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.08783511661023706[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 81.92 and Dec = 7.07 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 81.92  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 7.07  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 76.59, Dec = -25.22) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 76.59  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -25.22  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 500 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL][EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL]answer = absolute_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.028807767042693277. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.028807767042693277[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 34.32, Dec = 19.37) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 34.32  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 19.37  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 49.5 and Dec = -24.49 using Astropy?

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.027594824669346197. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.027594824669346197[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.06225853691752442. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.06225853691752442[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.05074450344473004. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.05074450344473004[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.038363362852248784. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.038363362852248784[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.027303951270665296. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.027303951270665296[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08881882261075566. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.08881882261075566[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 54.09, Dec = 12.83) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 54.09  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 12.83  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 5.44 and Dec = -11.45 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 5.44  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -11.45  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.016501712268776093. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.016501712268776093[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 75.68, Dec = -79.77) and (RA = 91.64, Dec = -87.21) using Astropy?

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 78.57, Dec = 0.1) and (RA = 2.58, Dec = -9.81) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 78.57  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = 0.1  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 2.58  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = -9.81  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 13.04, Dec = -51.09) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 13.04  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -51.09  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 24.39 and Dec = -59.16 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 24.39  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -59.16  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.02528136378360736. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.02528136378360736[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08967611468112834. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.08967611468112834[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08257564581310697. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.05394924310042202. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.05394924310042202[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 86.77 and Dec = 70.38 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 86.77  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 70.38  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 7.91, Dec = 83.74) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 7.91  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 83.74  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.006252849344711143. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.006252849344711143[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 35.48, Dec = -20.03) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.01608528408602059. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.01608528408602059[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 24.47, Dec = 10.0) and (RA = 71.77, Dec = 14.35) using Astropy?

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 36.13, Dec = -58.76) and (RA = 36.21, Dec = 12.89) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 36.13  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -58.76  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 36.21  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 12.89  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.004525826301582803. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.004525826301582803[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 85.5, Dec = 44.29) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 85.5  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 44.29  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 69.76 and Dec = 40.38 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 69.76  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 40.38  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.0599191654528889. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.07564375472275686. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.07564375472275686[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08604009333067913. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.08604009333067913[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.05854542838489664. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.05854542838489664[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 28.62 and Dec = -26.78 using Astropy?

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 23.16, Dec = 84.89) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 23.16  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 84.89  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.04800675612513982. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: A star located at a distance of 10 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL][EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL]answer = absolute_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.0348952968530745. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.0348952968530745[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.09493232763139232. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.054405916097323925. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.054405916097323925[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 20.96, Dec = 45.69) and (RA = 94.87, Dec = 8.34) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 20.96  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = 45.69  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 94.87  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 8.34  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 39.25 and Dec = 30.51 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 39.25  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 30.51  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 100 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 96.8, Dec = -21.74) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 96.8  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -21.74  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 69.9  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 82.15  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 29.88, Dec = -63.83) and (RA = 71.52, Dec = 17.72) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 29.88  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -63.83  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 71.52  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 17.72  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.09122707971389511. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.09122707971389511[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.09393853591088203. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.04382225922319152. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.07356461644123824. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.07356461644123824[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 36.51  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -50.41  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03847744609984802. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03847744609984802[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 97.39, Dec = 15.38) and (RA = 68.56, Dec = 73.53) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 97.39  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = 15.38  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 68.56  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 73.53  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.0579244187512295. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.0579244187512295[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.057859598554326146. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.057859598554326146[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.011518546066257752. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.011518546066257752[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 3.86, Dec = 49.38) and (RA = 85.94, Dec = 2.95) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 3.86  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = 49.38  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 85.94  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 2.95  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]
