prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.02860752852389742. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.02860752852389742[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 500 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL][EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL]answer = absolute_mag[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.07287109010088898. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.07287109010088898[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 60.86, Dec = -37.0) and (RA = 90.11, Dec = -35.63) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 60.86  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -37.0  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 90.11  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = -35.63  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 100 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL][EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL]answer = absolute_mag[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.06607952863318653. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.06607952863318653[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 53.18 and Dec = -8.16 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 53.18  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -8.16  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.020364646871051408. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.003830541671554544[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.05093977458866247. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.05093977458866247[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 63.43 and Dec = 15.54 using Astropy?

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 87.04 and Dec = 10.13 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 87.04  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 10.13  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.029608370991294798. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.029608370991294798[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03134764086768881. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03134764086768881[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03096700718928265. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03096700718928265[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.006510197809821217. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.006510197809821217[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 46.93 and Dec = 42.65 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 46.93  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 42.65  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.02549500185796837. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.02549500185796837[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 3.3, Dec = 19.76) and (RA = 87.97, Dec = 35.08) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 3.3  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = 19.76  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 87.97  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 35.08  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 17.2 and Dec = 49.4 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 17.2  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 49.4  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.09716442769214209. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.09716442769214209[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 52.36  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 30.15  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.021218562131573672. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 7.37 and Dec = 28.54 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 7.37  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 28.54  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 73.56 and Dec = -72.33 using Astropy?

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08129486618727555. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.08129486618727555[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 64.0, Dec = 76.13) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 44.74 and Dec = -58.68 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 44.74  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -58.68  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 11.3, Dec = 32.64) and (RA = 12.26, Dec = -2.25) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 11.3  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = 32.64  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 12.26  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = -2.25  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 10 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 12.76 and Dec = -33.25 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 12.76  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -33.25  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 60.62, Dec = -39.22) and (RA = 33.16, Dec = 22.84) using Astropy?

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.011746589466147718. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.011746589466147718[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 53.96, Dec = 1.59) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 53.96  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 1.59  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03750548373725271. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03750548373725271[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 71.13 and Dec = 50.44 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 71.13  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 50.44  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.056514579403054425. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.056514579403054425[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 10 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL][EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL]answer = absolute_mag[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 82.04 and Dec = -41.29 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 82.04  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -41.29  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 69.5, Dec = 30.36) and (RA = 2.16, Dec = -41.55) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 69.5  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = 30.36  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 2.16  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = -41.55  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.06460697071769962. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.06460697071769962[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.042281430021735046[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 64.79, Dec = -44.45) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.07606695610450942. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.07606695610450942[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 41.77 and Dec = 46.16 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 41.77  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 46.16  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 91.83, Dec = -75.01) and (RA = 76.82, Dec = 64.77) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 91.83  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -75.01  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 76.82  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 64.77  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 88.87 and Dec = 20.25 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 88.87  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 20.25  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 50 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL][EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL]answer = absolute_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 33.7 and Dec = 28.06 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 33.7  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 28.06  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 57.4, Dec = -24.0) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.07215262945521833. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.07215262945521833[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 10 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.04224793576182191. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.04224793576182191[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.017275743170240523. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 16.29, Dec = 73.91) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 16.29  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 73.91  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.038948518666928736. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.038948518666928736[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.060955012782862986. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.060955012782862986[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.0769736301173965. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.0769736301173965[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03947819596125274. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03947819596125274[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 86.74 and Dec = -38.29 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 86.74  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -38.29  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.0930602035710176. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.0930602035710176[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 34.03 and Dec = 39.94 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 34.03  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 39.94  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 10 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 4.52, Dec = 87.36) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 4.52  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 87.36  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.017508682334955783. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.017508682334955783[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.0446759870805316. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03008815053976668. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03008815053976668[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 98.58, Dec = -73.36) and (RA = 61.64, Dec = 11.67) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 98.58  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -73.36  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 61.64  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 11.67  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 42.93 and Dec = -7.22 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 42.93  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -7.22  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.016205345983483867. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.016205345983483867[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 43.34, Dec = 43.36) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
