prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 77.28, Dec = -55.12) and (RA = 54.07, Dec = 72.8) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 77.28  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -55.12  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 54.07  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 72.8  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08292805491526851. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.08292805491526851[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.032403676082173476. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 25.43, Dec = -44.31) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.04092517975844694. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.04092517975844694[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.020978774756601815. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.020978774756601815[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.05049806927238218. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.05049806927238218[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 64.24  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 37.04  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.0990801873657694. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.06268584661155137. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.06268584661155137[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: What is the name of the celestial object located at RA = 23.06 and Dec = -21.06 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 23.06  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -21.06  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Get the name of the celestial object[EOL]object_name = equatorial_coord.to_string('hmsdms')[EOL][EOL]# Print the name of the celestial object[EOL]print("Name of the celestial object:", object_name)[EOL]answer = object_name[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 14.46 and Dec = 24.02 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 14.46  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 24.02  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 36.48, Dec = -11.89) and (RA = 18.86, Dec = 30.21) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 36.48  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -11.89  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 18.86  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 30.21  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03194626520197084. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03194626520197084[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 15.81, Dec = -22.11) and (RA = 10.8, Dec = 45.25) using Astropy?

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.06531522633148386. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.06531522633148386[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 64.77, Dec = -12.97) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 64.77  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = -12.97  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 200 parsecs using Astropy.

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.07718436698549747. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.07718436698549747[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.07489361716377928. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08824747980570785. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.08824747980570785[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.08773013865804348. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03377211004465487. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.07368521643130703. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.07368521643130703[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.04123822189571544. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.04123822189571544[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 100 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL][EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL]answer = absolute_mag[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 100 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 50 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03369936378100215. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03369936378100215[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 65.74, Dec = -52.44) and (RA = 46.36, Dec = 30.51) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 65.74  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -52.44  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 46.36  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 30.51  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 36.18 and Dec = 83.13 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 36.18  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 83.13  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 500 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 500 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.

code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 27.42  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 86.97  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.014484636849102407. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.014484636849102407[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Calculate the orbital period of a planet orbiting a star located at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import G, M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Define the mass of the star[EOL]star_mass = 1 * M_sun[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the orbital period[EOL]orbital_period = (2 * np.pi * (distance**3 / (G * star_mass))**0.5).to(u.yr)[EOL][EOL]# Print the orbital period[EOL]print("Orbital period of the planet:", orbital_period)[EOL]answer = orbital_period[EOL]

prompt: What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b) of a celestial object located at RA = 42.68 and Dec = 65.35 using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial object[EOL]ra = 42.68  # Right Ascension in degrees[EOL]dec = 65.35  # Declination in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create a SkyCoord object for the celestial object[EOL]equatorial_coord = SkyCoord(ra=ra, dec=dec, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Convert the equatorial coordinates to Galactic coordinates[EOL]galactic_coord = equatorial_coord.transform_to('galactic')[EOL][EOL]# Retrieve the Galactic coordinates (l and b)[EOL]galactic_l = galactic_coord.l.deg  # Galactic longitude in degrees[EOL]galactic_b = galactic_coord.b.deg  # Galactic latitude in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Print the Galactic coordinates[EOL]print("Galactic coordinates (l, b):", galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]answer = (galactic_l, galactic_b)[EOL]

prompt: A star located at a distance of 200 parsecs has an apparent magnitude of 6.2. Calculate its absolute magnitude using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 50 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL][EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the apparent magnitude of the star[EOL]apparent_mag = 6.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 200 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the absolute magnitude[EOL]absolute_mag = apparent_mag - 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the absolute magnitude[EOL]print("The absolute magnitude of the star is:", absolute_mag)[EOL]answer = absolute_mag[EOL]

prompt: A galaxy is observed to have a redshift of 0.03003314078943913. Calculate its recessional velocity using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy.cosmology import Planck18 as cosmo[EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL][EOL]# Define the observed redshift of the galaxy[EOL]redshift = 0.03003314078943913[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the recessional velocity[EOL]recessional_velocity = cosmo.H0 * redshift * cosmo.comoving_distance(redshift)[EOL][EOL]# Print the recessional velocity[EOL]print("Recessional velocity of the galaxy:", recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s))[EOL]answer = recessional_velocity.to(u.km/u.s)[EOL]

prompt: Convert the equatorial coordinates (RA = 48.91, Dec = 64.59) of a celestial object to Galactic coordinates using Astropy. What are the Galactic coordinates (l and b)?

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 10 parsecs using Astropy.
code: [EOL]from astropy import units as u[EOL]import numpy as np[EOL]from astropy.constants import L_sun[EOL][EOL]# Define the absolute magnitude of the star[EOL]absolute_mag = 4.2[EOL][EOL]# Define the distance to the star[EOL]distance = 10 * u.pc[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the apparent magnitude[EOL]apparent_mag = absolute_mag + 5 * (np.log10(distance / u.pc) - 1)[EOL][EOL]# Print the apparent magnitude[EOL]print("The apparent magnitude of the star is:", apparent_mag)[EOL]answer = apparent_mag[EOL]

prompt: What is the angular separation between two celestial objects located at (RA = 35.12, Dec = -31.21) and (RA = 38.75, Dec = 75.84) using Astropy?
code: [EOL]from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord[EOL][EOL]# Define the equatorial coordinates of the celestial objects[EOL]ra1 = 35.12  # Right Ascension of the first object in degrees[EOL]dec1 = -31.21  # Declination of the first object in degrees[EOL]ra2 = 38.75  # Right Ascension of the second object in degrees[EOL]dec2 = 75.84  # Declination of the second object in degrees[EOL][EOL]# Create SkyCoord objects for the celestial objects[EOL]coord1 = SkyCoord(ra=ra1, dec=dec1, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL]coord2 = SkyCoord(ra=ra2, dec=dec2, unit="deg", frame="icrs")[EOL][EOL]# Calculate the angular separation[EOL]angular_sep = coord1.separation(coord2)[EOL][EOL]# Print the angular separation[EOL]print("Angular separation between the celestial objects:", angular_sep)[EOL]answer = angular_sep[EOL]

prompt: Given a star with an absolute magnitude of 4.2, calculate the apparent magnitude at a distance of 100 parsecs using Astropy.
